trans-unit.source: Deploy Azure Resources Using the Compute, Network, and Storage .NET Libraries
trans-unit.target: Deploy Azure Resources Using the Compute, Network, and Storage .NET Libraries

trans-unit.source: Learn to use some of the available clients in the Compute, Storage, and Network .NET libraries to create and delete resources in Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Learn to use some of the available clients in the Compute, Storage, and Network .NET libraries to create and delete resources in Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Deploy Azure Resources Using the Compute, Network, and Storage .NET Libraries
trans-unit.target: Deploy Azure Resources Using the Compute, Network, and Storage .NET Libraries

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to use some of the available clients in the Compute, Storage, and Network .NET libraries to create and delete resources in Microsoft Azure.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to use some of the available clients in the Compute, Storage, and Network .NET libraries to create and delete resources in Microsoft Azure.

trans-unit.source: It also shows you how to authenticate the requests to Azure Resource Manager by using Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: It also shows you how to authenticate the requests to Azure Resource Manager by using Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial you also need:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial you also need:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure storage account</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure storage account</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Windows Management Framework 3.0</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>Windows Management Framework 4.0</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: It takes about 30 minutes to do these steps.
trans-unit.target: It takes about 30 minutes to do these steps.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Add an application to Azure AD and set permissions
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Add an application to Azure AD and set permissions

trans-unit.source: To use Azure AD to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager, an application must be added to the Default Directory.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure AD to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager, an application must be added to the Default Directory.

trans-unit.source: Do the following to add an application:
trans-unit.target: Do the following to add an application:

trans-unit.source: Open an Azure PowerShell prompt, and then run this command:
trans-unit.target: Open an Azure PowerShell prompt, and then run this command:

trans-unit.source: Set the Azure account that you want to use for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Set the Azure account that you want to use for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Run this command and enter the credentials for your subscription when prompted:
trans-unit.target: Run this command and enter the credentials for your subscription when prompted:

trans-unit.source: Replace {password} in the following command with the one that you want to use and then run it to create the application:
trans-unit.target: Replace {password} in the following command with the one that you want to use and then run it to create the application:

trans-unit.source: Record the ApplicationId value in the response from the previous step.
trans-unit.target: Record the ApplicationId value in the response from the previous step.

trans-unit.source: You will need it later in this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: You will need it later in this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an AD application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an AD application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can also find the application identifier in the client id field of the application in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: You can also find the application identifier in the client id field of the application in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Replace {application-id} with the identifier that you just recorded and then create the service principal for the application:
trans-unit.target: Replace {application-id} with the identifier that you just recorded and then create the service principal for the application:

trans-unit.source: Set the permission to use the application:
trans-unit.target: Set the permission to use the application:

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a Visual Studio project and install the libraries
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a Visual Studio project and install the libraries

trans-unit.source: NuGet packages are the easiest way to install the libraries that you need to finish this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: NuGet packages are the easiest way to install the libraries that you need to finish this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You must install the Azure Resource Management Library, the Azure Active Directory Authentication Library, and the Computer Resource Provider Library.
trans-unit.target: You must install the Azure Resource Management Library, the Azure Active Directory Authentication Library, and the Computer Resource Provider Library.

trans-unit.source: To get these libraries in Visual Studio, do the following:
trans-unit.target: To get these libraries in Visual Studio, do the following:

trans-unit.source: Click File > New > Project.
trans-unit.target: Click File > New > Project.

trans-unit.source: In Templates > Visual C#, select Console Application, enter the name and location of the project, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: In Templates > Visual C#, select Console Application, enter the name and location of the project, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the project name in the Solution Explorer, and then click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: Type Active Directory in the search box, click Install for the Active Directory Authentication Library package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type Active Directory in the search box, click Install for the Active Directory Authentication Library package, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the page, select Include Prerelease.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the page, select Include Prerelease.

trans-unit.source: Type Azure Compute in the search box, click Install for the Compute .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type Azure Compute in the search box, click Install for the Compute .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: Type Azure Network in the search box, click Install for the Network .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type Azure Network in the search box, click Install for the Network .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: Type Azure Storage in the search box, click Install for the Network .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.
trans-unit.target: Type Azure Storage in the search box, click Install for the Network .NET Libraries, and then follow the instructions to install the package.

trans-unit.source: Type Azure Resource Management in the search box, click Install for the Resource Management Libraries.
trans-unit.target: Type Azure Resource Management in the search box, click Install for the Resource Management Libraries.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to start using the libraries to create your application.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to start using the libraries to create your application.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Create the credentials that are used to authenticate requests
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Create the credentials that are used to authenticate requests

trans-unit.source: Now that the Azure Active Directory application is created and the authentication library is installed, you format the application information into credentials that are used to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Now that the Azure Active Directory application is created and the authentication library is installed, you format the application information into credentials that are used to authenticate requests to Azure Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Do the following:
trans-unit.target: Do the following:

trans-unit.source: Open the Program.cs file for the project that you created, and then add the following using statements to the top of the file:
trans-unit.target: Open the Program.cs file for the project that you created, and then add the following using statements to the top of the file:

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to get the token that is needed to create the credentials:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to get the token that is needed to create the credentials:

trans-unit.source: Replace {application-id} with the application identifier that you recorded earlier, {password} with the password that you chose for the AD application, and {tenant-id} with the tenant identifier for your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Replace {application-id} with the application identifier that you recorded earlier, {password} with the password that you chose for the AD application, and {tenant-id} with the tenant identifier for your subscription.

trans-unit.source: You can find the tenant id by running Get-AzureSubscription.
trans-unit.target: You can find the tenant id by running Get-AzureSubscription.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method in the Program.cs file to create the credentials:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method in the Program.cs file to create the credentials:

trans-unit.source: Replace {subscription-id} with your subscription identifier.
trans-unit.target: Replace {subscription-id} with your subscription identifier.

trans-unit.source: Save the Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Save the Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Add the code to register the providers and create the resources
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Add the code to register the providers and create the resources

trans-unit.source: Register the providers and create a resource group
trans-unit.target: Register the providers and create a resource group

trans-unit.source: Resources are always deployed to a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Resources are always deployed to a resource group.

trans-unit.source: You use the <link><linkText>ResourceGroup</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>ResourceManagementClient</linkText><title></title></link> classes to create the resource group that the resources are deployed to.
trans-unit.target: You use the <link><linkText>ResourceGroup</linkText><title></title></link> and the <link><linkText>ResourceManagementClient</linkText><title></title></link> classes to create the resource group that the resources are deployed to.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to create the resource group:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to create the resource group:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Create a storage account
trans-unit.target: Create a storage account

trans-unit.source: A storage account is needed to store the virtual hard disk file that is created for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: A storage account is needed to store the virtual hard disk file that is created for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to create the storage account:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to create the storage account:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual network
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual network

trans-unit.source: A virtual machine is most productive when it is added to a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: A virtual machine is most productive when it is added to a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to create a subnet, a public IP address, and a virtual network:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to create a subnet, a public IP address, and a virtual network:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Create a virtual machine
trans-unit.target: Create a virtual machine

trans-unit.source: Now that you created all of the supporting resources, you can create a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Now that you created all of the supporting resources, you can create a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to create the virtual machine:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to create the virtual machine:

trans-unit.source: Image vhd names change regularly in the image gallery, so you need to get a current image name to deploy the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Image vhd names change regularly in the image gallery, so you need to get a current image name to deploy the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: To do this, see <link><linkText>Manage Images Windows using Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>, and then replace {source-image-name} with the name of the vhd file that you want to use.
trans-unit.target: To do this, see <link><linkText>Manage Images Windows using Windows PowerShell</linkText><title></title></link>, and then replace {source-image-name} with the name of the vhd file that you want to use.

trans-unit.source: For example, "a699494373c04fc0bc8f2bb1389d6106__Windows-Server-2012-R2-201411.01-en.us-127GB.vhd".
trans-unit.target: For example, "a699494373c04fc0bc8f2bb1389d6106__Windows-Server-2012-R2-201411.01-en.us-127GB.vhd".

trans-unit.source: Replace {subscription-id} with the identifier of your subscription.
trans-unit.target: Replace {subscription-id} with the identifier of your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Add the code to delete the resources
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Add the code to delete the resources

trans-unit.source: Because you are charged for resources used in Azure, it is always a good practice to delete resources that are no longer needed.
trans-unit.target: Because you are charged for resources used in Azure, it is always a good practice to delete resources that are no longer needed.

trans-unit.source: If you want to delete the virtual machines and all of the supporting resources, all you have to do is delete the resource group.
trans-unit.target: If you want to delete the virtual machines and all of the supporting resources, all you have to do is delete the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Add the following method to the Program class to delete the resource group:
trans-unit.target: Add the following method to the Program class to delete the resource group:

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the Main method to call the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Run the console application
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Run the console application

trans-unit.source: To run the console application, click Start in Visual Studio, and then sign in to Azure AD using the same username and password that you use with your subscription.
trans-unit.target: To run the console application, click Start in Visual Studio, and then sign in to Azure AD using the same username and password that you use with your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Press Enter after each status code is returned to create each resource.
trans-unit.target: Press Enter after each status code is returned to create each resource.

trans-unit.source: After the virtual machine is created, do the next step before pressing Enter to delete all of the resources.
trans-unit.target: After the virtual machine is created, do the next step before pressing Enter to delete all of the resources.

trans-unit.source: It should take about 5 minutes for this console application to run completely from start to finish.
trans-unit.target: It should take about 5 minutes for this console application to run completely from start to finish.

trans-unit.source: Before you press Enter to start deleting resources, you could take a few minutes to verify the creation of the resources in the Azure preview portal before you delete them.
trans-unit.target: Before you press Enter to start deleting resources, you could take a few minutes to verify the creation of the resources in the Azure preview portal before you delete them.

trans-unit.source: Browse to the Audit Logs in the Azure preview portal to see the status of the resources:
trans-unit.target: Browse to the Audit Logs in the Azure preview portal to see the status of the resources:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an AD application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an AD application</linkText>
